content:
Posted: January 9, 2015
Early Access Review
								Although the title itself may make it seem it'll probably be one of those unfunny games like Goat Simulator, this game is pretty fun.When I picked up this game, I honestly thought the community would be a dread and that I wouldn't be able to play a serious game without people flicking everywhere. However, I have met some great people on this game, and so far, there's been very limited annoyance.Workshop support is what really makes this game stand out in my opinion. Without it, it'd may still be a good game, but the workshop allows many other games to be played, whether that is card games or board games. There is an endless stream of games to play created by users, so you're not restricted to a few games that are preset. You can pretty much find any classic board game or card game on there, and if it's not on there, well you should make it before anyone else takes that idea, or wait for a smarter and more productive person to do that for you.However, the game itself doesn't have a lot of players and it can be sometimes tricky to get in a public game. I only see about 5 or 6 public servers, out of the 100s of servers there are, which is slightly disappointing, but that is not really the games fault, but this can be sometimes frustrating as you are only forced to select a few games, and not all of them you will like, so you would have to host a server and wait for a long amount of time to see of anyone wants to play go fish with you, which surprisingly, most people don't. Go fish, more like go ♥♥♥♥ yourself.Also, this game cannot really be played by yourself, bit of a ♥♥♥♥ing no brainer but it's true. If you didn't know that you can't play chess by yourself, I'm pretty concerned onto how you have the intelligence or attention span to read this. I don't even see why to put in a singleplayer option sometimes. It's really boring and nearly impossible to play by yourself. The whole point of single player is to play by yourself, how in God's name can I play checkers by myself? The only game I've seem to found to play myself is solitaire, However, I won't lie that the single player feature is useful, but very limited to being useful. Apart from the custom content creator, if you have friends at your house, you can whip out the single player, but it may be sort of awkward as you would need to constantly switch places to move the piece on the computer. I've never tried it, but what's the whole point of playing monopoly on the computer solo with my friend next to me, when I can just get the ♥♥♥♥ing game out in real life? If you do not have a certain game though, then this can be pretty useful in some cases, but only with board games. However, I do like to play online with friends and sometimes strangers.It's a shame that not more of my friends have this game, as it's spectacular fun and I especially like this game I guess for my interest in board games and card games.  There's a few glitches in it, and it can be annoying at times, but I would say get this game if you're interested in board games, card games etc. If not, then this game may not be for you, but there are plenty of games on the workshop.

												What can I say about this that has NOT already been stated? This is my favorite title on steam. Why?Lets start with the fact that nearly all my board games that I own are available on here. The ability to play them or to test out different strategies in a quick manner is something that has caused my gaming group to play more together. I am also able to save my games no matter where I am at.So if me and my friends want to play a game that we know we cannot get through, but would love to be able to continue it later, well.... WE NOW HAVE A WAY TO DO THIS! Gone are the "Take a picture of the board, write down what we had here...." While nothing can ever replace the physical game, and the enjoyment that a game night with a bunch of local friends, it does provide a great way to play with my friends that have moved away, as well as introduce different people to the joy that board games. Tabletop Simulator has given me a way to expand my physical board game collection, introduce people to games, play with friends from a far, and test out strategies, all for $20. I recommend this to anyone who enjoys board games, or perhaps are interested in getting started, and want to learn just how different and enjoyable board games can be from video games.10/10

content:

												To clarify, this is an engine to play board games. You can play almost any game you can think of. There have been weekly or at least monthly updates, and they keep adding more features the community requests. I had one issue with the workshop not syncing, and the devs actually worked with Valve to get the issue resolved quickly.The only problem for new players, is finding games to join. You need to look for groups that host TTS games. An easy one is Tabletop Simulator Club (look for that group in Steam Groups).Once you play a few games you will realize how great this engine/sandbox is, and if you find a few people to play online with, you will have hours of entertainment.Last comment, I had to chance to meet the developers at PAX Prime, and they both seemed extremely nice. Can't wait to see where they take TTS next, or their next project.

I've got many hundreds of hours of fun yet to be had with this piece of software.If you're at all into board games and have friends you can play with over the net, this is for you.

number of helpful: 14 of 14 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								After following this up from Greenlight, this game is truly incredible. The amount of fun you can have with people from around the world is immense. The Steam Workshop really adds a level of creativity to the game.People can make their own games from Uno to Monopoly. They can create their own special versions of games, like a unique Nintendo Monopoly, or a Minecraft Monopoly. I am currently the owner of three Workshop Items. The possibilities are really endless.People can import these games and host a Multiplayer server for up to eight people from around the world. Of course if you live further away you're going to have more server lag unless the host has amazing internet. Currently LAN support is not available, but that's not a feature I usually use in games anyway. You can set passwords for your game room for a private match. You can disable table flip, hands for non-card games. There used to be a problem where people would join a game, table flip and leave, but now the game has a delay before a person can do that even if table flip is on. There are really a lot of options.Rules are enforced by the host, simply meaning if they don't play properly then why would they allow them in the room? The host can kick/ban a player, or mute a player if they're squeaking or something through their microphone.The people on this game are mostly friendly. To filter out annoying people though you can put "(mic)" or "(mic needed)" in the title, then you can ask them if they can talk when they join the game. People are usually nicer when they have to speak to others with their voice rather than text speak. Seat requesting has been suggested before but has not been added yet.The single player version of this can be played on your own or with others if you share a mouse. This isn't really something I'm too interested in either. This mode is usually the place where people make custom games designed for multiplayer, or simply to get used to controls and mess around. Of course there are single player games you can play, if that's what you're in to, like Solitaire.The physics in this game is really fun to play with to. There is a gravity multiplier which changes the gravity effect of objects in-game. People have made tabletop tennis with a coin. Throwing things around, watching things fly off as you flip the table.  Rolling a dice around a game board. Everything is really well done.I get the most fun though out of talking to people through microphone. Talking through chat just doesn't cut it for me, especially in a silent game as it currently has no game music. I enjoy arguing with people over competetive games such as Story War and Once Upon A Time. I recommend you get a microphone before getting this game in order to have a better game experience, unless you just want to play quiet games.Performance wise the game is excellent, and should run on low-end computers as well as high-end. All the game really has to load is a single table and the amount of things on the table. Performance will likely droop if you're hosting though, but for me this doesn't really show any considerable FPS change. The game looks good on Medium to Ultra, but starts to look bad if you go any lower. (Not that you should need to.)Unfortunately there are tabletop games which are just not possible to recreate at the moment such as Mouse Trap or Dingbats, but hopefully due to the fast updates this game has these games should be possible to recreate in a few weeks/months or so.The developers are amazing and listen to the community. My best advice would be to ask/suggest things on the Berserk Games forum as that's where they mostly hang out. They push out a new update every week or so with new and fun features for the community to try out and squashed bugs. It's great fun being a part of the Early Access community and helping to shape the game into a game everyone would want to be a part of.If you're interested, you should watch some videos and see what all the fuss is about.Anyway, I highly recommend this unique game for anyone who likes playing tabletop games in real life (which is pretty much everyone). This has great replayability.10/10 - Fun!

Posted: March 24
												Tabletop is a genius product.  If you're a tabletop gamer and can't find any local games, Tabletop Simulator is for you.  If you're a tabletop gamer that just wants to play online once in a while instead of getting a group together, Tabletop Simulator is for you.  If you want to try out a game before you go pick up a physical copy, Tabletop Simulator is for you.  In fact regardless of any of those thing, Tabletop Simulator is probably for you.There is a rich and growing workshop in Steam, to the point that I'm yet to find something I want to play that doesn't exist as DLC or Workshop.  The interface is fantastic, the tools are fantastic, and the ongoing development is fantastic.I really can't say enough good things about Tabletop Simulator.  For the price tag, you really can't beat it.

number of helpful: 13 of 13 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 5, 2016
												Tabletop Simulator is an amazingly simple, enjoyable game. Whether you meet new friends, play with old friends, or meet new friends while playing with your old friends, this game is amazing regardless! Play games you played as a child, find new games you think will be fun, play classic games, and play games you've never even heard of before, with your beloved pals. Going outside is for normies. With Tabletop Simulator, you can experience the joy of playing with your real friends, online friends, and completely random people while in the comfort of your own home and computer. Play games such as Chess, Checkers, Pictionary, Pool, Poker, Mahjong, Chinese Checkers, Candyland, Monopoly, Sorry!, Dominoes, Jenga, Eels and Escolators, Apples to Apples, Dungeons and Dragons, Black Jack, Roulette, and games you've literally never heard of!This game is versatile. You can play board games, play all sorts of D&D games and even set up your own boards and dungeons, and learn new ways to have a blast with your friends. Be prepared to flip tables, laugh, rage, and appreciate with this game.I purchased this game when it was on sale for $10.00. I know that $20 is a bit much for a stupid table simulator game, but it is worth it my friend. I suggest this game to anyone who has or has not friends, because you can always make great friends on this game by joining or hosting servers free to the public.

content:
Posted: March 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								 For anyone thinking about buying this game I can honestly tell you that this has been one of the most enjoyable purchases I have made on steam. The workshop mods alone make this game well worth the price. I started first looking through the steam workshop and found that any tabletop game I could think of was there and ready to play. Which is great because it is rare I have all my game playing friends anywhere near my tabletop collection. So its nice to be able to roll some virtual dice and play some board games online. The gameplay can be a bit awkward sometimes (kind of depends on the game) but use the hotkeys for functions like, lock down game piece, or zoom in on card, can really help speed up game play and keep you from knocking pieces all over the board. If you do manage to destroy your board or someone gets mad and flips the table, you can simply undo step and the board has been reset to the last play before desaster struck. Another thing you might wonder about is hiding your cards so other players cannot see them. There is an area over your "seat" that you can place cards without others seeing, however if you need a larger area simply use the fog of war tool and your cards are safe from other players view.  In the time I have played Tabletop Simulator I have purchased a few tabletop games that I wouldn't have otherwise, due to the cost of some tabletop game titles. Being able to try them out with expansions and get a feel for the game really made the difference for me and I then had no problems sinking the money into the real thing. The game is constantly growing with more from the workshop and polish from the developers. Once again this is well worth the investment and has endless reply value.

content:
Posted: August 18, 2016
Product received for free
This was given to me as a gift back in 2014Something to enjoy with friends that are out of reach but want to play a board/card game with them. Table flipping is only funny when appropriate, otherwise it'll be annoying and rude. If you're going for that 1000 flips achievement, don't make it a priority along with the hour benchmarks.This is a good way to try out your 3D modeling & graphic skills for pieces, bags, cards, dice, background etc. Can even upload a custom image to the table (square or rectangle). See if you can create 3 original workshop items to share that isn't already made. :PDo note though and be warned, if your lobby is public it must be appropriate for everyone, otherwise the devs may revoke your key if informed. Be sure to make your lobby private by putting in a password; can do whatever you want in a private lobby. (Yes, can even upload nsfw images on the table or puzzle pieces, go nuts; just make sure it's not part of a workshop item or you'll be in bigger trouble.)$15 is worth it if you plan to play board/card games often with your friends, or make custom stuff with 3d modeling or art, otherwise I would wait for a sale for like $10.-----Check out more games I see that deserve more attention from my curator group:BluePaw's Underrated Games ListJoin and/or follow if you wish.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2014
Early Access Review
								Tabletop Simulator is essentially a virtual version of board and card, an idea that has been done before, but not on the level that tabletop simulator has done, where you are simply given the cards, the chips, and boards for you to set up nearly any game you want. Of course, this is expanded much farther by the steam workshop, where people sumbit games that range from original and genius board games, or just a copy of a well-known game (Monopoly, Uno, etc.)  Everyone in the game has a hand cursor and matching color, and they can interact with anything on the table at any time, the rules for must be set up by players and obeyed for the sole reason of playing correctly (which of course opens the doors for a number of trolls and griefers)  The game, of course, is still in early access and, suprisingly, is updated quite often. People often say that people release early access games and then never update because they've made their money. For some games this is true, but Tabletop Simulator is consistenly updated and so far it looks like the final release will be great. If the game were released now it would still be great! However, it's obviously not perfect. Interaction with objects can sometimes feel awkward and dropping pieces when you aren't looking from a birds eye view is usually guesswork when you aren't placing the piece 3 inches from the camera. Despite its flaws, Tabletop Simulator has been fantastic so far, and it promises to be even better at release.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2016
												This is a physics sandbox where you can basically play any 2D tabletop game in any manner you please. No rules are hardcoded (although Lua scripting is supported for convinience!) and a large variety of tools are available to perform every action you please. They're officially licensing full commercial board games for digital conversion as their growing library of DLC, and most any other game you can think of has already been faithfully recreated in the Steam Workshop.If you are an artist of any kind, you can effortlessly upload new content to use in any way you please. Entirely custom boards, cards, figures, dice, and other trinkets are all things you can produce for any purpose you need.One downside, it unfortunately has a lot of trouble with vertical layouts, making it impossible to play Battleship with upright boards, difficult to play Connect-4 as originally intended (although if you lay it down as a slope it works much better), and very nearly impossible to play 23rd Century 3D Chess unless you're in Vive VR mode.It also tends to have some difficulty simulating the rest of the room, beyond the table. The DLCs add entirely custom table and 3D room models, but when you flip the table, you flip the room with it.

Early Access Review
								This is my first Review. I started playing this game on Friday and put 28 hours into it by Sunday morning. This software is a simple yet amazing concept. Board game lovers everywhere should purchase Tabletop Simulator. There are over 2000 mods in the workshop that replicate some of your favorite games. Anyone can create or import their own boardgames. The community so far seems amazing. I've encountered only 2 or 3 "trolls". I used the term "trolls" loosely because a couple of them were just children being children. The host options let you rewind, kick, ban etc so that they have very little influence on the rest of the game. I highly recommend this game. I have already purchased another copy for my guest account so I can let my friends try it out and play with me.

content:
Posted: April 27, 2015
Early Access Review
								Before I played my first multiplayer game using Tabletop Simulator, I knew I was going to enjoy it. Tabletop Simulator lays the foundation for you to reconnect with old friends that you used to game with as well as meet new friends that play the same games that you do. It is a toolbox allowing you to unlock nearly every experience you could have sitting at a normal table except you and your friends can now be thousands of miles apart and everyone has the best seat.The most important aspect of enjoying Tabletop Simulator is understanding the controls. In the beginning, they can be a burden if you don't spend a small amount of time learning how everything works. Take the time and explore all the different ways you can interact with cards, dice, and pieces. Once the controls become second nature, you can instead focus on what you're playing and not how you're playing it.For me, any and all network issues have been resolved. The game plays smooth and everyone can see everything in real time. Tabletop Simulator can also handle a crazy amount of individual pieces before it begins to struggle -- many more than you would ever use in even the most involved miniature or Euro game.Lastly, Berserk Games is working hard to make the experience even better. The game is advanced enough now, in my opinion, to be released, but they are finding even more features to add and updating on a regular basis. They listen to their user base and are working to make the best product they can. When you're looking for an Early Access success story, this is the example you should give. I am a proud supporter!

content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												Despite Tabletop Simulator being in Early Access, it's very much worth purchasing in my opinion. I can't speak too much about the default tabletop games it brings such as dominoes or chess. However, my friends and I have put in nearly 100 hours of game time already because we've found this to be a very fun, social game to play. We've downloaded and installed at least a dozen board games and it's been really fun trying them out.  We've played Cards Against Humanity, Fluxx, Ascension, King Of Tokyo, Munchkin, Red Dragon Inn (a drinking game that we've had a lot of fun playing :P ), Dixit, Betrayal at House on the Hill, Once Upon A Time, to name a few. It's been a fun experience playing all these board games that we normally wouldn't have been able to play online with friends. A few of us have even dabbled into some light Role Playing which we didn't really ever try before and found that we've enjoyed it.The game isn't without its bugs here and there but I can honestly say it's nothing game breaking. The developers have done a fantastic job with fixing bugs and releasing frequent updates. Every time we've found ourselves asking in game "Wouldn't it be great if they added X, Y, Z?” they seem to add those things in within the next update or two and then some. I feel that the developers listen to their community and actually take their suggestions and implement them. Overall, I most definitely recommend this game for hours of silly fun with friends. If board games are your thing or it's something that you've never really tried but are curious about, I absolutely recommend you give Tabletop Simulator a try.

content:
Posted: January 24, 2016
												Generally speaking, this game ist not much more than a physics sandbox with some tools for administrating up to 8 players and supporting custom models. But this is enough to open up unlimited possibilities for boardgame geeks, don't let the screenshots from the store fool you! This sim can handle way more than Chess, Checkers and other common stuff you'll find online en masse.That said, the workshop support is the heart of this application, because it allows modders to recreate every boardgame, cardgame, tabletop or physically existing game. Lots of historical stuff you'll never get your hands on (except you're willing to pay high collector's prices) like games from Avalon Hill or those nasty american nuclear-themed games from the atomic age. Here's a random selection of well-done workshop items you should try out:- Advanced Civilization- Bohnanza (popular german cardgame)- Carcasonne- Settlers of Catan (including Star Trek mod)- Risk (LotR-mod / Star Wars-mod and more)- Exploding Kittens- Zombie Dice- Starship Troopers (based on the novel, not on the movie)- Alien - Fallout-Monopoly- Escape from Colditz- X-Wing Miniature Game- Warhammer - HotelThere are no limits: Scan your favorite game's cards, reference sheets and rules, import 3D-Models and preserve this stuff for all times. Clearly a totally unterrated game, or better to say, tool. 10/10: Why did I have to wait until 2015 to get my hands on an application like this?

content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
Early Access Review
								Want to play chess with marbles, Mahjong tiles, and bears?  Sure, you can do it.How about playing poker with Uno cards, Dominion cards, and Magic: the Gathering cards?  Yep, why not?Can you place your checkers on the red spaces, and king them by replacing the checker with a queen from chess?  Sure, but why not replace it with an Ent figurine instead?How about stacking up a bunch of blocks into a castle, and then knocking it over with pony figurines?  Well♥♥♥♥♥♥ who doesn't love a good game of Angry Ponies?Go ahead, be a nonconformist; play your board and card games the way you want.  Build crazy structures from game pieces, impress your friends with magic tricks*, stack up some dominoes and topple them over, or...well, play any game you want.  Even one you made up.  Tabletop Simulator simply gives you the table and the ability to spawn whatever pieces you want, and leaves you to do whatever you wish.  And with the ability to create a custom board/cards/figurines, the possibilities are endless.Oh, and if you get♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off, you can flip the table and watch the board and pieces fly.  Best (and worst) feature ever made.*Quick Silver does not guarantee that your friends will be impressed, or that all magic tricks are possible in Tabletop Simulator. Results may vary. Please use illusion and sorcery responsibly.

												If you want to fully enjoy this game, you need to be social ;)But seriously, you would need to be able to play with either random people or friends (if ya hav any) if you want to have the most fun.If you have just bought the game, you might get bored easily from all the basic games.. The reason for this is that any game that you want to play (Besides the basics) are found on the Steam Workshop for Tabletop Simulator, as it is community based, or purchasable DLCs, which are also fun.You do not have to spend half of your freetime to set-up and clean-up, as they are usually set up for you, with a few things you have to do yourselves. Leaving the boring time to a minimum, and the entertaining times to the max! That is if you are not playing chess (Just kiddin).The biggest part of the game, of course, is the workshop, where all the games found! With over 13,500 Workshop items and more to come! Most (Not All) of the community are great people, each game I play has different types of people, so the games never gets boring! And for the price of one game, you would now have access to 13,000+ games that are usually twice the cost of Tabletop!The last, and most important part of this game... Table Flipping Overall, I rate this game a 9.9/10. Depending on the time, the place can be a tad quiet, but there will always be at least 5 games up at a time, if not, more.

content:
Posted: November 1, 2014
Early Access Review
								Tabletop Simulator is a game where players can host various games, old and new, based off content from the Steam Workshop. A host will have the ability to invite up to 8 players depending on the game. The host and players controls a hand cursor that can be used to interact with game pieces.As host you have the ability to duplicate, spawn, and deal game pieces out to players. Cards and pieces can be hidden in front of the player for privacy when developing strategy.The games contains no music, cinematics, or storyline. Exactly what you would expect from a simulation game. I do enjoy the amount of content that is released on the Steam Workshop for this game. However the controls can take some getting the hang of, even after viewing the tutorial. As well as issue getting pickup groups going with random players.I believe Tabletop Simulator is a must for any board gaming enthusiast. A great addition to any gaming clan or guild's game nightI would recommend this game.

number of helpful: 7 of 7 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 4, 2016
												So I've been eyeing this game for a while before I bought it and let's just say I'm so glad I got it while it was on sale. Not because it wasn't worth the price oh no no! Because of humble bundle I was able to donate to a good cause AND get an amazing game that's worth way more than what they're charging to be honest.A good thing to keep in mind is this game is like a box of 100 games. Many of which I've been able to play over and over with the fun increasing over time rather than dying down like old games. If you're bored of a game or would rather play something else, just select a new board game, take a little time to learn it and boom! Pros:  Replayability is unrivaled HUGE variety Most part decent community Active community VERY modable! Cons: There's only 3 cons for me and I'd rather explain them then list them: Playing during off hours: Playing TTS while the USA is asleep is a little more difficult to have players join your game. I've noticed the community goes down 2/3s during the late/really early hours of the night but if you have a 2-3 player game that's decently popular, it's not really a big deal. Playing a board game you want to play: Now this is kind of a small issue since everybody has different game style tastes. As for me, wanting to play long strategy and war games, unless you have friends, it's a bit hard to find people that: 1. won't leave mid way 2. won't quit while you're explaining.You always haft to go into a game expecting people don't know how to play which bugs me but hey, you get around it. The ADD stricken kids or small part of the community: There's a good chance you'll run into the younger audience which is fine in some cases, hell, I've ran into a 13 year old more mannered than a 21 year old here. HOWEVER, you'll run into some who will fidget with pieces, rush things, and even flip the table before they leave. (All good though as you're able to rewind gameplay GOD BLESS) It's just annoying at times but like I said, this doesn't happen that often.Also, some people either will join and sit there trying to mess with your players or try to ruin the board by throwing pieces. Simply just kick them and everything will be fine! Like I said, there's a rewind function AND a blacklist so you can keep people off your servers :)All in all, this game is REALLY amazing and is awesome if you have a group of friends or you're bored and need something new to play.

content:
Posted: July 26, 2016
												If you have friends who like any sort of tabletop games, you will all love Tabletop Simulator. It's introduced me to a dozen different games I'd never played before that I went out and bought because they were great. Playing games with friends is easy and fun.If you don't have people to play with though, it's a bit harder to find or start a game. It's a big time investment to explain a new game to a half dozen people who've never played before, so expect people to quit halfway through the explanation and have to start all over again with someone else. Because of that, most of the games you can join on public servers are ones that are relatively easy to explain or have a lot of people in the general player base that already know how to play. There's probably 20-30 different public servers open at any given time with [currently] popular games like Secret Hitler, Betrayal at House on the Hill, X-Wing, Codenames, Red Dragon Inn, Epic Spell Wars, Magic: TG, Bang!, etc. being the most commonly featured.

number of helpful: 7 of 7 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 8
												Being a fan of board games/tabletop gaming, I stumbled across Tabletop Simulator some time ago as a means of playing Eldritch Horror through one of the projects in the workshop. Not only did the TS version cut down on setup/dismantle time, it happened to be a functional and more convenient way to play the game, even with people over distances. One of the most magical parts about board gaming is that you are face-to-face with the other players and get to interact with them in person while you're playing the game. Unfortunately, given our busy schedules and the distances between us, we are not always able to meet in person and lay out our games on common table. TS gives people a chance to play board games virtually, conveniently, and practically, wherever they may be, and cuts down on the prep time which makes these games more accessible to us board game enthusiasts. In addition, TS also has just about every single board game out there available for download on the workshop or as top-quality DLC from the steam store. Without further ado, here's to many more hours of tabletop gaming to look forward to! And to be clear, I fully recommend this game if you're into board games!!!

content:
Posted: April 24, 2014
Early Access Review



YouTube™ Video: Tabletop Simulator: Early Impressions 

			Views: 6,108		

			Tabletop Simulator: Early Impressions We take a look at the early access "Tabletop Simulator", a versatile sandbox game that features virtually any table top game you could imagine.		

Above is my video impression of the game.I'll be honest, judging strictly from the screenshots and some video, I didn't expect that much from tabletop simulator. After some random online games filled with trolls I expected even less. But once I managed to have a game of MTG with'n tabletop sim with mature, and well organized players I was sold! I saw the light, I see the potential and grand scope that this game has to offer. I am actually incredibly impressed by how well it functions once players are there to play, rather than to troll.The scope and concept, as well as it's versatility is incredibly impressive. Truly the name is as accurate as it could possibly be. It simulates what it's like to play these tabletop games IRL. There's no score keeping by the game, it's upto the player. There's no digital ref restricting your moves, it's up to the player. It honestly does feel close to the real thing.Overall, Tabletop Simulator has a few rough edges as of now, but the potential of this is quite impressive.Pros:- Mimics real life tabletop experience very well- Extremely versatile sandbox that will allow for virtually any table top games to be mimiced here.- Brave and unique design choices- Very fun with well coordinated playersCons:- Graphics are a little crude currently- Too many trolls online- Almost require friends or trusted players to enjoy

content:
Posted: June 9, 2015
												An oddly good timewaster, Tabletop Simulator is the simulator to buy if you want to play tabletop games. The controls feel a little wonky but oddly they work really well with lots of undo options should something spectacular screw up. There's also perhaps the best feature: table flipping. Also easily undoable.Anyway if you have friends or family far away and want to play games like yahtzee, monopoly, chess, checkers, snakes and ladders you name it in a 3D style game and not in some glitchy 2D flash game with questionable ads you found on a Google search, this is the game to get. It doesn't require a lot of computer power to run and, with some coaching, may even be easy enough for your grandparents to use. Mine got the hang of chess anyway. It's also a lot of fun being able to play a game like yu gi oh and have every single card available even if it's a challenge sifting through all ten thousand of them.Overall highly recommended, this simulator is better than I ever would have expected

number of helpful: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 21, 2015
												Tabletop Simulator is really a hard thing to review, as it is really what you make it to be. The sole purpose as to why I got this was for the Tabletop Roleplaying aspect of it. I am a Game Master and have found many ways to use this before or during my game sessions. I am the founder of the Tabletop RPG Gamers League, a Group that is made up of people, players of tabletop/pen and paper games, and I definitely recommend this to all fo them. Anyway, lets continue on to the pros and cons listsNOTE-This review is based solely on the RPG/Game Master features and uses for Tabletop Simulator.Pros-Unlimited Features, you can do literally do whatever you want to with this thing. If Tabletop Simulator doesn't have an asset that you need like a castle piece or knight model, you can just make one! It literally has unlimited potential for all of your Game Master needs.Consistent Updates, the developers are still expanding the base resources, specifically the RPG assets. This is great news for those interested in these assets, us Game Masters that is.Multiplayer, you can literally play your favorite tabletop game with your friends using this game, either through the internet or using hotseat gameplay. For the internet part, connecting is very easy and allows the Game Master to set the rules.Many others, but lets continue to cons...Cons-Complicated Controls, the controls are not to simple for beginners, remembering which button does what is hard early on. Once you have played with the controls for a while you will get a feel for them. The tutorial tells you how to use the controls, but thats about it.Inefficient Menus, finding the piece you are looking for takes to long, not because they are hard to find, but because you have to search through the menu, then sub menus, then more sub menus. It just takes to long, but I can live with it for now, although it would be nice to eventually change the menu set up. I guess you will never be able to reproduce a real tabletop session 100% in a virtual game.Conclusion-Overall, this is perhaps at the moment the best and most realistic means in recreating the actual feel of tabletop gaming, not just roleplaying games, but any game. I believe that this could eventually become the standard for PC tabletop roleplaying, and look forward to seeing what the developers do with this. This is a must have for any Game Master, or anyone who just really likes playing tabletop games!May your adventures be many and always end in reward!-Donoknight, Founder of Tabletop RPG Gamers League

content:
Posted: March 2
 Fun and Intuitive, Still Feel Bad About Playing Unlicensed Games.I am currently running Tabletop SImulator to participate in boardgames I rarely get the chance to play. So like those in the Steam Workshope I am equally guilty of playing games I can't afford or do not own. Let's just be honest here, that's what is happening here. The Tabletop Simulator workshop boasts loads of games from various publishers. I try not to worry or even contmeplate over the legality of playing these games, but nonetheless, I try to play them all. As for the game system itself ... it is a very easily learned and intutitve system of 2D VR manipulation. I wish the same could be said for some of the workshop games, but ... beggers can't be chosers. Do I recommend it? Yes.

number of helpful: 9 of 12 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 17, 2014
Early Access Review
								Tabletop Simulator is in it's infant stages currently. The game revolves around simulating a tabletop and physics, and allowing players to play a variety of games (or create their own!) on said tabletop.Where the game currently shines is the development team. They've formed a close-knit tie with their community and are currently listening to community feedback in a way few other games can. Many features have been straight from the communities mouth, and they're willing to engage the community and discuss with us upcomming features, plans, and gameplay. If there's no game on a table you're interested in playing, TTS probably isn't for you. This isn't going to magically make DnD, Chess, or Munchkin more fun. But if you do enjoy tabletop games, then playing with friends and strangers online on TTS is the way to go.

content:
Posted: April 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is my favourite purchase of the year. I absolutely love it. Either grab one of your favourite boardgames or set them up yourself for the game, and then play it with all your online friends. It's amazing! It does have a great deal of flaws still, many related to controls, physics and small oversights, but even then everyone I've played it with (some 8+ people now) has utterly loved it. I cannot recommend this enough if you love boardgames and you want to be able to play it with your long distance buddies.I will say though that if you want this PURELY for D&D or other such pen and paper things, do NOT get this. It works, it absolutely does, but there are other far better and FREE alternatives out there. I really can't recommend this game if you're doing it for pen and paper roleplaying at all. Everything else though, heck yes. I'm pressuring all my friends into getting this.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 29, 2015
Early Access Review
								Do not discount this game as a simple board game sim; Believe me when I say it has surprised me time and time again.Tabletop Simulator is a fantastic party game, the ideal solution to anyone who has ever wanted be able to play that one board game with all of their distant friends, or even those nearby without the ridiculous mess that usually goes into them.This game comes with a standard pack of classical tabletop games, such as Checkers, Chess, Mahjongg, and even some RPG tools in case you want to play old-school miniatures. That, however, is not where this game shines. Its true worth is the fact that Workshop Integration and an active modding community allows you to play almost any tabletop game imaginable, from Cards against Humanity to Pokemon Master Trainer to Munchkin to Liar's Dice to Sellswords to Triple Triad. Given time, almost any game, no matter how obscure or how niche, will find its way to the Workshop and therefore be playable for you and up to eight friends.PROS:-a large amount of agency is afforded to players in order to provide an optimal game experience-an almost limitless library of modules is available via the workshop, giving access to hundreds of distinct games-a tutorial explains most of the obscure commands and keys fairly effectivelyCONS:-some functions that one might expect aren't available (no way to import backgrounds independent of game-types, some kind of inventory functions for players for items other than cards, etc.)Ultimately, the game is absolutely worth it if you and yours have ever wanted to play a particular tabletop game without all the hassle of having to be cluttered around a messy game board or table. I absolutely recommend this game and its various workshop modules.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 5, 2014
Early Access Review
								We live in a crazy and busy world at times. But what's more apparent, is the fact that we're finding ways to be more connected with one another. We live in a digital age where a lot of the things we do have a tendancy to revolve around some electronic device. Board gaming has been one of those hobbies that strays away from such things and it is something I can appreciate. Despite the convenience and power we practically wield through even just a phone these days, it's nice to take a break from it to gather with friends and forget about such things for the sake of a more personal and human interaction.But, we realize that such gatherings may not always work out, or perhaps you just happen to not have anyone nearby that shares the passion of these games. Ironically, through the use of computers, such experiences can at least achieve second best. Tabletop Simulator allows one to share those experiences with others over great distances, but most importantly, it still keeps that personal feel to a degree that one may not necessarily regard as digital or artificial. The way it plays out with physics and actually seeing what others are doing are the hallmark of what helps make board gaming interesting and engaging. Sometimes because of it, we may accidently tip over a piece or put something where we didn't intend. As much as it seems like a minor inconvenience, such little details are all the same thing we may tend to find in real life scenarios. Obviously, I realize not everyone is on board with such things and there are other solutions out there that fit the bill for those seeking a refined, perfected, and orderly take on tabletop gaming.There's plenty to experience right out of the box with classic board games and cards. Also, the possibilities for bringing in custom content are grand, even given the limitations the program may have in the beginning. In time, we'll see more potential unlock from there. Imagination is the only limit I can see.Quite aptly as it is named, Tabletop Simulator seeks to simulate the tabletop gaming experience. I think what makes this program a great entry is that it doesn't try to perfect the board gaming scenario and make it efficient. Rather, to bring it as close as possible to those who cannot as easily do so, but keeping it as organic as possible. To me, that's where the real beauty shines through.

content:
Posted: March 9, 2015
Early Access Review
								So far, the only gripe that I have with this game is that when you have active searches on stacks of cards and you absolutely need to undo something, the deck you are searching ends up clipping into the table, rendering the object intangible. I know not if this is an issue that can be fixed, though the preservation of decks when undoing actions would be really nice to see.In regards for suggesting features, I would like to see the implementation of books (perhaps imported from documents on your hard drive?), though one might question the feasibility of such an implementation because at the end of the day, Tabletop Simulator is really just a physics sandbox with a few features to help simulate card, tabletop, and/or board games and I understand if the pages of said books would prove far too taxing on the game's physics engine.Other than that one gripe and suggestion I have, I have yet to notice any jarring issues besides the one above so yes, I can safely recommend this game as it does what it does really frickin' well.

content:
Posted: May 25, 2014
Early Access Review
								Tabletop simulator is a game that has everything in the title. 1. I immediately went on the workshop for it and found Cards Against Humanity, with 4 core sets included and more coming in. 2. You can make anything. friend made hexagonal chess in a while, as it's a real chess variant that was famous in britain. 3. Played CAH with friend and lots of people joined, and we carried that into a 4 player chess game when it ended. 4. You can flip the table at any point. And then undo it. 5. It controls amazingly. you can zoom in to the cards, make them smaller/bigger, put them on the side, put them into your hand, flip them to hide them (it autohides if it's in your hand, only you can see it) 6. Went onto the workshop and found an exact recreation of an 80's boardgame for the first Legend Of Zelda game, complete with instruction booklet. 10/10 playing that tomorrow It supports a lot of people, and it has voice chat too.Edit: forgot to say you can make your own boards, card sets, and anything and rules for each variant are on the side, and you can just click a button to see them all We played uno 10/10

Posted: July 20, 2015
												It's the natural progression you'd expect to happen from real-life tabletop games sliding on into the virtual world. I wouldn't recommend this game if you plan on playing with strangers, but when you're with friends- it's just like the real thing. It's hilarious and fun, but the game runs on honesty since it's quite literally a simulator- allowing you to flip the table in a fit of rage, or steal another person's cards right out of their hand, or plop down a tablet on the table only to open up a web browser to bring up hardcore gay porn. I'd say Card Against Humanity is the most popular thing to play in this Simulator, but the game offers to many games you can play, even tabletop RPG crap.  Feature Preformance   Storytelling / Intrigue 8   Graphics 10   Sound 5

content:
Posted: April 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								You might say "Wow, board games! That's fun" sarcastically, but this game is surprisingly engaging. You can play traditional card games as well as mod your own. People have modded many games including Munchkin, Cards Against Humanity and Monopoly in and you can too with basic photo editing skills. It is tons of fun to play with someone online and the D&D elements are still basic as hell but functional.Should you buy it? If you ever wanted to make your own board/card game and/or want to play some board games with someone over the internet... WITH PHYSICS. If you come here just for the D&D it's basic, but a good game can be managed, but I would hold up a bit with the D&D, but overall the best early access potentional out there.

content:
Posted: May 2, 2015
Early Access Review
								Allows you to play any board game or card game with people not in the same room.That's the pitch and it's a big one. However, the implementation knocks it out of the park.At it's core Table Simulator  is, well a table (duh) that you have complete control over. Whether you're manipulating cards, placing models,  rolling dice, control is easy intuitive and tight. This places Table Simulator as a prime candidate for modding.And it has flourished, players have imported every card and board game under the sun to be played with others online and all they had to do is import the art assets. Just like playing a physical version the players themselves manage the game mechanics, no additional scripting or AI is needed, only the players themselves are needed.

Posted: June 24, 2016
												After all this time, I will give this game a thumbs up because I believe this is the quintessential party game everyone that uses steam every other day should have. This game is what you make it. If you chose to not be social, not make a mod, not use other mods, afraid to learn rules, or afraid to host games, You will not get anything out of this game. This game is a great tool to have sit down time with friends and playboard games or even learn new boardgames since the workshop is littered with the biggest selection I've seen in a long time. But due to the game not having a great way to find common interest amongst strangers and a lot of servers are passworded. I'd recommend this game if you are a tabletop enthusiast or a friend wanting to buy the 4 pack.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 30, 2016
												This game is difficult to review because it's almost positive in a lot of ways. The best way I could put it is, Tabletop Simulator can be reviewed based on how much you enjoy other tabletop games like Dungeons and Dragons, Warhammer, Secret Hitler, Cards Against Humanity and even Monopoly. Tabletop Simulator resembes a application specialized in mimicry. It's a faceless manupilator, it takes the form of any thing you want like a 6IV Ditto from Pokemon. It captures you attention, you purchase it thinking it's great until you realize, there's nothing to fancy about it. That is, until you realize you can literally pirate any game ever, import it into its file directory and it just takes of from there, it becomes your life now- for a little while. How did I get into MTG? Tabletop Simulator. How did I get into Warhammer lore? Tabletop Simulator. How did I get into Secret Hitler? Tabletop Simulator. I am telling you, as long there are trending tabletop games out there, Tabletop Simulator will always be something we cherish and something tabletop developers want to remand but really should be thanking for all that free advertisement!

content:
Posted: May 7, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is one of the most simple and yet most ingenius ideas I have ever seen and I recommend it whole heartedly. If the idea of playing almost any board game you can think of over the internet appeals to you then pick this game up now.This game has allowed me to play games ive never gotten a chance to play before and I have a lot of fun just browsing the rooms and seeing whats being played. There are no rules, you just sit down and play. This game is also amazing as a simple tool for building your own games. Im a game designer and this game lets me make virtual versions of my games that I could potentally use for playtesting. I could playtest my games from the comfort of my own home. And with eventual Steam Workshop support this could be a truely amazing thing.There are a few kinks that need working out. The custom board and card features could be a little more user friendly but there totally usable and I imagine it will get worked out in later patches.As a hobbist or even a creative mind this game is a must buy. If the idea of bringing all your friends from around the world together for a game of Monopoly sounds awesome to you then pick this up.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 25, 2015
Early Access Review
								Want to play something original with your friends?Want to play with your friends and family without buying a bunch of board and card games outside?Want to create board and card games?How about playing with others online (total of 8 players) and learn new games?Bored of other games?GET THIS GAME!Pros:- Has a variety of tabletop games- Easy to learn controls- Can create custom cards, boards, pieces, figurines, and tables- Host a multiplayer server without portforwarding- Save a game you made in singleplayer and share on the workshop or with online players- Become a Game Master and control how a game is played- Do things on the tabletCons:- Important to have some friends or family to play with you, or find a game on the server browser- Still some bugs and glitches, but nothing major- When host leaves, the server is closed and everyone is kicked- Rewind or undo button shuffles your hand if you're playing card games that involves some kind of organizationtl;drGood and fun game with friends or online players, though there are a few minor problems that stook out to me.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 5, 2015
Early Access Review
								We played four-player Settlers of Catan last night.  No built-in rule handling or anything, just the board, dice, stacks of cards, whatever, and occasionally we did silly things like pick up whole stacks of cards or forget to collect resources or knock over the Robber token moving stuff around...and I have to say it was a hell of a lot more fun than if the game rules were implemented and automatic.  The whole thing felt very human.  Also we spent a lot of time drawing♥♥♥♥♥♥♥on the table waiting for our turns to come around.I don't think I'd want to try playing this with people I don't know well, especially internet pickup games, but for people I don't see often enough in person but still want to hang out with, definitely A++++++ would act like a dork again.  You definitely need to use the tutorial to have any idea what the controls are since they're not _that_ intuitive, but that only takes like five minutes and then you're good.  I mean there's only so many buttons you can press to move pieces around a table.Sometimes our voice chat transmission dropped out--on two different machines, so not a fluke of my hardware.  Not sure what's up with that.  Also I feel like it would be really tedious trying to set this up for RPG stuff, like setting up all the fancy walls etc.  But that's super tedious in the real world too, and you can set things up ahead of time and save the table to reload later, so I guess it works.Currently looking at importing a bunch of custom models and seeing how well that works.  We need to have a tea party!...I'm probably up for gaming with people I know any time.

content:
Posted: November 11, 2015
												This software is always evolving and the way game developper/publishers can also use this software to promote/sell their games is making it a very interesting option.I consider this a tool for games; as it is supporting as many as you can think of as long as it plays on a table and by rounds. Kind-of.  I would say in solo to make/test your own or make table maps for your latest RPG levels it is great and really relaxing.  It comes with its own editor if you can come up with a stable image hosting site (yes unfortunately it seems it won't rely entirely to Steam workshop to host pictures but I can understand why if we want to develop later games and retain ownership).  It can also be played hot seat as many folks turn by turn in the same house. And finally, when microphone functions don't bug one way or another (but it can be resolved using Steam voice chat), do a whole 2 to 8 players game.  You can add to that a spectator and a GM if RPG is your thing!I can say, for nostalgic folks of the time we met all in the same house to have a real game night gathering without smart phone on the side, but empeched by being far away from familly and friends, or in hospital, or contagious etc...  It is great to break distance limitation and isolation.There are many great features I would like to review here but, I still continue to find them as I go and more features were added since I bought it and since I continue to play it.I would love to buy an additional 4 pack this Christmass, except... as I learned from Steam, once we have a copy the 4 pack must go to someonelse that you have to enthrust to regift the additional 3 copies to the rest of your friends you were hoping to make the gift.  It is truely the only minus part of it.Apart that, TTS is just what you will make out of it.  ^^  Make of it a good use!

Posted: April 23, 2016
												This game is great because the possibilities are endless. Just like the game title says, virtually anything can be played that requires top of a table. The mods is where it’s at. With more than 8,000 mods available you can find a lot of most popular board games, so you can play them for free instead of actually buying the physical copies. But to play this game, you definitely need some friends. If you don’t have any you could probably find people to play with on forums or within the game itself. Tabletop Simulator is an excellent time killer if you want to relax, chat, laugh, and have fun with your friends.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 14, 2016
TL;DR Great to play board games with your online friends, without the extra hassle of setting up.Score✰82%✰  ProsThousands of Board GamesMassive replay valueConsControls are fiddlyNot all mods get updatedGameplay:Tabletop simulator is a dream come true for anyone who has ever loved engaging in board games, and just can't find the company to play them with. The core aspect relies on mod-based contributions, like Garry's Mod – except for tabletop games. There are thousands to choose from, ranging from things like RISK, Monopoly, Cards Against Humanity – to Chess and countless other party style board games. Some mods are intricately rendered with original skins for playing pieces, others are cleverly designed and planned out. There are original games, and a good chance to find any of the board games you've loved back at home or for those times where you're forced to put up with extra relatives.The initial premise, of course, is that you're presented with a table, faced against a randomly generated background (which incidently is also moddable.) Depending on if you choose a private or open game will decide if you play with your friends or with strangers. I would probably recommend playing with friends, as there is a high tendancy for random players to “flip” the table, which consequently ruins the progress of whatever is there.  The controls of Tabletop can take a little getting used to, since sometimes a wrong movement can accidentally sabotage things that you don't want sabotaged, or reveal your card hand. (Which then makes you flip the table because it was a really good hand.) This is probably my only real gripe – the chance of a game being killed before it hits the real action, and the fiddly controls. Also, perhaps, people who have excellant mods but don't update them, or don't include rules with their games. :(The gameplay offered is whatever mods you choose to download and whenever you find people who will want to sit around and play all those classic party games. I played Pictogram! Cards Against Humanity, Uno, Threeway Chess and WoW Guess Who! In one session with a few other friends. It's brilliant to be able to pick through the list and agree on games together without doing the packing and unpacking that goes beforehand with physical board games. Obviously there's something special about doing that as well, but when your friends live across the map, this is the perfect opportunity to get them together and tackle that desire to find people willing to sit around long enough for board game sessions.Want moar? Click here to join my steam group and Click here to follow my curator page!

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 7, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is one of the most simple and yet most ingenius ideas I have ever seen and I recommend it whole heartedly. If the idea of playing almost any board game you can think of over the internet appeals to you then pick this game up now.This game has allowed me to play games ive never gotten a chance to play before and I have a lot of fun just browsing the rooms and seeing whats being played. There are no rules, you just sit down and play. This game is also amazing as a simple tool for building your own games. Im a game designer and this game lets me make virtual versions of my games that I could potentally use for playtesting. I could playtest my games from the comfort of my own home. And with eventual Steam Workshop support this could be a truely amazing thing.There are a few kinks that need working out. The custom board and card features could be a little more user friendly but there totally usable and I imagine it will get worked out in later patches.As a hobbist or even a creative mind this game is a must buy. If the idea of bringing all your friends from around the world together for a game of Monopoly sounds awesome to you then pick this up.

content:
Posted: March 25, 2015
Early Access Review
								Want to play something original with your friends?Want to play with your friends and family without buying a bunch of board and card games outside?Want to create board and card games?How about playing with others online (total of 8 players) and learn new games?Bored of other games?GET THIS GAME!Pros:- Has a variety of tabletop games- Easy to learn controls- Can create custom cards, boards, pieces, figurines, and tables- Host a multiplayer server without portforwarding- Save a game you made in singleplayer and share on the workshop or with online players- Become a Game Master and control how a game is played- Do things on the tabletCons:- Important to have some friends or family to play with you, or find a game on the server browser- Still some bugs and glitches, but nothing major- When host leaves, the server is closed and everyone is kicked- Rewind or undo button shuffles your hand if you're playing card games that involves some kind of organizationtl;drGood and fun game with friends or online players, though there are a few minor problems that stook out to me.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 5, 2015
Early Access Review
								We played four-player Settlers of Catan last night.  No built-in rule handling or anything, just the board, dice, stacks of cards, whatever, and occasionally we did silly things like pick up whole stacks of cards or forget to collect resources or knock over the Robber token moving stuff around...and I have to say it was a hell of a lot more fun than if the game rules were implemented and automatic.  The whole thing felt very human.  Also we spent a lot of time drawing♥♥♥♥♥♥♥on the table waiting for our turns to come around.I don't think I'd want to try playing this with people I don't know well, especially internet pickup games, but for people I don't see often enough in person but still want to hang out with, definitely A++++++ would act like a dork again.  You definitely need to use the tutorial to have any idea what the controls are since they're not _that_ intuitive, but that only takes like five minutes and then you're good.  I mean there's only so many buttons you can press to move pieces around a table.Sometimes our voice chat transmission dropped out--on two different machines, so not a fluke of my hardware.  Not sure what's up with that.  Also I feel like it would be really tedious trying to set this up for RPG stuff, like setting up all the fancy walls etc.  But that's super tedious in the real world too, and you can set things up ahead of time and save the table to reload later, so I guess it works.Currently looking at importing a bunch of custom models and seeing how well that works.  We need to have a tea party!...I'm probably up for gaming with people I know any time.

content:
Posted: November 11, 2015
												This software is always evolving and the way game developper/publishers can also use this software to promote/sell their games is making it a very interesting option.I consider this a tool for games; as it is supporting as many as you can think of as long as it plays on a table and by rounds. Kind-of.  I would say in solo to make/test your own or make table maps for your latest RPG levels it is great and really relaxing.  It comes with its own editor if you can come up with a stable image hosting site (yes unfortunately it seems it won't rely entirely to Steam workshop to host pictures but I can understand why if we want to develop later games and retain ownership).  It can also be played hot seat as many folks turn by turn in the same house. And finally, when microphone functions don't bug one way or another (but it can be resolved using Steam voice chat), do a whole 2 to 8 players game.  You can add to that a spectator and a GM if RPG is your thing!I can say, for nostalgic folks of the time we met all in the same house to have a real game night gathering without smart phone on the side, but empeched by being far away from familly and friends, or in hospital, or contagious etc...  It is great to break distance limitation and isolation.There are many great features I would like to review here but, I still continue to find them as I go and more features were added since I bought it and since I continue to play it.I would love to buy an additional 4 pack this Christmass, except... as I learned from Steam, once we have a copy the 4 pack must go to someonelse that you have to enthrust to regift the additional 3 copies to the rest of your friends you were hoping to make the gift.  It is truely the only minus part of it.Apart that, TTS is just what you will make out of it.  ^^  Make of it a good use!

Early Access Review
								The idea behind this game is pretty fantastic.  You can scan in your favorite family game board, upload models of the pieces on the workshop, and it will be completely playable.  With the sandbox environment, anything you can do with your tabletop at home, you can potentially do here.Unfortunately, most of the games on the server list are locked, and the few that are open are not very well coordinated.I recommend this game as something to play with friends who also own it, but not as something that can be easily jump into without them.I've also had problems with the Linux version crashing when selecting from a menu consensually, but the game is early access after all.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 18, 2015
												I remember seeing this game being featured on the Steam Store. After that, I immediately bought it for myself, and a copy for a friend.Tabletop Simulator has nice physics, and perfect gameplay. Although this was a game about playing games, which let you throw pieces around and screw up the board, playing games is easy, as the game will correct your piece to the nearest slot when you set down a game piece.The game already comes with a few different modes, such as Chess, Checkers, Chinese Checkers, RPG set, Reversi, Poker, Solitaire, etc. Along with these different modes, the modding community on the Steam Workshop makes new content for my friends and I to play, and constantly adds to the amount of gameplay content for the game. I've downloaded many mods, such as 3 player chess, Risk, Battle of Burgundy, and many more.At some point, I tried to convince another friend to buy it, but he refused, so I just gifted a copy to him. Tabletop Simulator is a great game, with all types of board games packed into one video game. I would absolutely recommend this to a friend.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2016
												Best video game purchase of the year.I love board games. I have closets full of all sorts of games. The problem is that I don't have closets full of local friends.Everyone got married and or had kids and moved away or grew up, so my pool of potential friends to actually hang out with has been significantly reduced over recent years.This game allows my friends and I to get together and play some games again!A buddy of mine backed "Kingdom Death: Monster" as a kickstart project, and we've been waiting to try it out for a long time. Over the holidays, he came home to visit and we played. It was incredible. Now we can play it on TTS, too. Excellent.I have a crap-load of Heroscape sets, but it's a pain to get people together and deal with al the set-up/take-down time. This game makes it possible to play Heroscape again. Another check mark.Really, if you like board games, you need this.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2015
												Imagine your favorite board game, in 3D, on your PC, with legit multiplayer. No more wasting time resetting props or putting anything away. A lot of famous board games are available on the workshop including Monopoly and Scrabble. Oddly enough this game also includes a set of tools: A calculator, a tablet that has a built in web browser based on chrome, a digital clock, notes, even a music player that looks like a common MP3 player. These tools can be spawned in multiplayer by the host which can be very helpful.It's very well optimised, doesn't eat ram and doesn't overstress your graphics card. Me and my friend spent 7 hours playing board games when I got the game last night(12/22/2015). I gotta say, I'm impressed.

number of helpful: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 1, 2014
Early Access Review
								An earlier review I wrote of this game was just a table-flipping emote, but honestly, that's not the whole game.Table-flipping, while entertaining, is overrated.The real fun of the game comes from actually playing the games, or trying to and failing miserably due to the fact that it's a physics-based tabletop game simulation. You'll often be fumbling around with specific parts due to the controls, or having your friends toss your stuff off the table randomly, or have the admin spawn unrelated parts which someone then swings around. These may seem like bad things. They are, but they make the game so much more enjoyable.At the same time, you can actually play serious games of things like chess, checkers, etc and have more fun than you would playing them in just about any other video game.Just get it. It's beautiful.

number of helpful: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 3, 2016
												Have you ever found yourself playing a video game and thinking to yourself, "I wish I was playing a board game instead, like the good ol' days." No?...oh. Me neither....Well I mean if it's on sale for $5 and you've got a few friends to play it while while you chat over Skype I guess. The reason why video games are nice is because they have rulesets programmed into them, with board games you have to do all of the busy work yourself: moving pieces to specific locations carefully, doing all of the calculations and math in your head, trying not to accidentally break the rules or mess something up, and resisting the urge to revert to your childhood instincts of wanting to flip the board over.Rating: Worth $5. Wait for a steam sale.

content:
Posted: May 18, 2014
Early Access Review
Gameplay - This game allows you to pretty much play ANY tabletop game (as long as the community has made it), and if it isn't created you can make custom decks and boards to make your own (or an already made game).Community - The community on this game are mostly nice, I have entered a few games not knowing a single thing about the game I joined and so far all of them have explained to me how to play it (even the VERY complicated games), there isn't many bad things about the community, but every now and then you get players who join tables who try and ruin other players experiences, but they can get banned from that table by the host and any damage can be undone, so no harm done.Final - I highly suggest this game if you enjoy playing any sort of tabletop game, you can play it with your friends or with public players online, eventhough it's alpha, I dont see any major problems with the game at the moment so it is worth buying.

content:
Posted: February 10, 2015
Early Access Review
								My friends and i are wanting ot have a poker night but we find it hard to travel so we decided to buy this game. We were told we could play games such as Poker, Pokemon, UNO and a lot more and its true!With worksop mods their are games such as Yu-Gi-Oh, many versions of Monopoly, Top Trumps, Trvia Pursuit, Scrabble and so many more. This game is something great. The graphics are rather nice but could do with a little more. The UI is great and easy to understand and its great fun to play with friends. We regullary have poker nights on this game and play Monopoly an dmany others as its such great fun.This game is currently priced at 10.99 GBP which....... in my opinion isnt worth it. I would pay about 7 GBP - I got mine for 3 CSGO Keys. BARGAIN!I feel that their needs to be more worksop mods, although there are already a lot, their could be so so so much more. I am currently creating a trvia pursuit for teens game. And its very easy to make your own mod for this game.Overall:Graphics: 8/10 (although it is mod related)User Interface:  10/10 very easy to useWorksop: 8/10 wide variety of games but not a lot of great gamesPrice: 6/10 i wouldnt pay 10.99  GBP for itPlay Time: 9/10 this game can provide countless hours of funHighly recommended

content:
Posted: April 3, 2016
												Had low expectations, but I was pleasantly surprised! This game is so good that I've spent well over $100 on it already on buying it for others to enjoy. I truly love this game, and got to the 100 hour mark within my first week. If I had more free time, I'd already be up to 1,000 hours. Can't recommend it enough!If you decide to buy it, I'd recommend learning Secret Hitler, Eldritch Horror, Arkham Horror, & Sheriff of Nottingham; all fun games! I'd be willing to teach you any of them if you add/PM me, that's how invested I am in this game.9/10, would be perfect if some bugs were fixed, mainly in matchmaking and ping. The issues are usually resolved by entering/exiting the server, and port forwarding helps a tonne. Expect a lot from this game!

content:
Posted: January 21, 2016
												This is one of the best purchases I have ever made. I bought this on Winter Sale 2015 for $10 and have definitely gotten my money worth. I thought I would have to convince my friends to get it to have a good time but it turns out the community playing it is awesome. I have yet to find myself trying to find a game and not succeeding. Additionally, it is very easy to host games and people almost always join and play with me!I've created a few mods which was relatively simple.My main complaint is that the controls are a little bit difficult to learn and I wish some of the functionality could be mapped to keyboard. However, once you figure it out it becomes second nature and the controls no longer get in the way.If you're worried about dropping the money to get this and not being able to find people to play with, don't worry, the community is awesome and you will be playing games right away. Additionally, everyone is extremely friendly. However, make sure you have a microphone as it is *almost* required to play most games. There is text chat but very few people use it.

Gameplay - This game allows you to pretty much play ANY tabletop game (as long as the community has made it), and if it isn't created you can make custom decks and boards to make your own (or an already made game).Community - The community on this game are mostly nice, I have entered a few games not knowing a single thing about the game I joined and so far all of them have explained to me how to play it (even the VERY complicated games), there isn't many bad things about the community, but every now and then you get players who join tables who try and ruin other players experiences, but they can get banned from that table by the host and any damage can be undone, so no harm done.Final - I highly suggest this game if you enjoy playing any sort of tabletop game, you can play it with your friends or with public players online, eventhough it's alpha, I dont see any major problems with the game at the moment so it is worth buying.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
Early Access Review
								A really great concept with fantastic mod tools (recreate your favorite board game!) and a realy solid hook: play tabletop games with your friends who are far away.Unfortunately, actually playing the games is akin to playing games with just your elbows. Games with precise movements become nightmarishly tedious, and even deckbuilder card games become a bit of a chore the longer the games progress. My friends often refuse to play some of our favorite complex games just because of how unwieldy the physics and controls are.Yes, this game is a huge step in the right direction of online board games.Yes, this game will allow you to create/test/play your own games, as well as many retail games.No, this will not substitute playing games in person with your friends- at least not without advancements in input tech.Best with simple, social games that don't require too much object handling.Recommended only for board game geeks. (and friends of board game geeks)

												A good test of Tabletop Simuator on Steam is . . . can it handle the various game elements of a classic social board game like Cosmic Encounter® and is the Tabletop Simulator evironment a place where the game can be played easily and naturally, just like you were sitting at a table playing a game of Cosmic with your friends?It can and does. Passing with flying colors! Plus you can play with anyone anywhere in the world at anytime, talk to and hear other players, save games to complete later, and bring in your own homebrew aliens to test and play.As one of the original designers of Cosmic Encounter I am thankful for all the skill and hard work by Berserk Games to create this wonderful environment for our game.Also, a note for game designers - this is a perfect environment to use for creating and play testing new game concepts.
