number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												Tabletop simulator is an interesting "Game" if you can call it that, it's very different from any other game in that it's up to the players to come up with their own rules for play. Tabletop simulator is a board game simulation program that lets people play board games you would normally play in the same room across the internet. The game provides a decent amount of premade games and pieces to use with the steam workshop also supplementing this with custom models and game pieces. Essentially the game is very basic at it's core but is loose enough in it's functions that allows a very wide range of things you can do.I would of liked to see a few more features such as more board options and better drawing tools but it can be overlooked as they still update the game infrequently.I would also recommend having a few friends to play with as it's kind of the whole point of the game, I wouldn't recommend the game if you plan on playing alone or are uncomfortable playing with random players.Overall I'd say this is a great engine for creativity that could potentially provide endless hours of content if you can come up with the games to play or use the ones on the workshop.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 10, 2015
												Clearly inspired by Wolfire Games' Desperate Gods, Tabletop Simulator is by far my favorite game in the Steam library. While I may not have many hours, when I do play, there's always so much fun to be had! Tabletop Simulator is a physics engine that gives you a few starting props, and says "have a go." It's up to the players to decide what games they build and play.You can import your own 3D assets into the game, for tokens or other game pieces, and if you're not a great artist, try using some pictures (that you have the rights to, hopefully) of your favorite card games to build a game deck and play that instead!With Steam Workshop support, some of your favorite games are already available to download and play! Cards Against Humanity, for instance, is a game licensed under Creative Commons, allowing the game to be hosted in many forms on the Workshop, and many players have even made their own cards for use in the game!Give it a buy, and you won't be sorry! Just make sure to grab the four-pack, so you can play with your friends! Guaranteed to cause one of you to kill the other eventually.

content:
Posted: July 31, 2016
												It's time we forget about all the "monopoly online 2015 free" games on our tablets and phones. Here comes the Tabletop Simulator, the ultimate tool for having fun. You've always wanted to play some board games with someone you don't see really often? TTS will help. TTS provides the best experience out there, it doesn't "hold your hand" - rules are enforced by players, not the game itself. As a master (if the game needs one), you can always do some miscalculations - just like the real board game. No automatic stuff (unless it's scripted, it's possible, but not necessary).The game feels great. I've been waiting for a game like this for a couple of years, and finally it's here.Final score: 10/10.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 10, 2016
												I don't know why I didn't write a review for this game sooner, but after 200+ hours here it goes.In short: This game is amazing. It allows me to play board games with my friends all across the world. Not only that, but it also lets me try new games that I would have never had the gumption to go out and buy. Sometimes I've played games and it's been okay, other times I've played the game and immediately went to amazon to buy the physical copy.I first encountered the game in 2014 and after watching the video just didn't understand the potential. It seemed like one of many physics simulators and didn't seem to have much use beyond messing around and flipping tables.  Boy was I wrong. Since then, I've bought 8 copies of this game for me and my friends (because I'm a pushy board gamer that wants to play and they were hesitant to try). We have all greatly enjoyed the interface while not perfect, is incredibly funcitonal.The developers are also second to none. They are constantly releasing updates that greatly increases the functionality of the game. When they added scripting it basically made it a new game, greatly increasing the functionality of what the users could mod. Now they've added custom states and the ability to import unity asset bundles.This is no longer just a tabletop simulator, this is now a full fleged tabletop engine that offers an insane amount of freedom to board game developers. Not only does it help bring people together to play games at a distance, it also allows those interested in board game design to create prototypes without pilfering games for tokens.In the end... Awesome game. If you play board games or are even remotely interested, buy this. Don't even think about it, just click buy.

content:
Posted: May 25, 2014
Early Access Review
								Of course it gets the reputation "hurr flip table" but in all seriousness, with workshop support, the numbers of games are endless. In addition, the sandbox-y controls work suprisingly well. Being able to play Chess, Netrunner, or even smaller games like Boss Monster and Dominion with strangers over the internet is just wonderful. Certainly a unique title.EDIT:The workshop support is growing ever larger, as is my time with this game. Only recently have I picked up the chest and along with it the ability to save objects. With this, I've been playing A LOT of Magic the Gathering with friends and random people, making a few more friends. This game is just wonderful, and my enjoyment with it never seems to diminish.

content:
Posted: July 16, 2014
												Have you ever wanted to play those card games from your youth such as Uno and the pokers without leaving the comfort of your computer? Of course not, you're twelve and don't know what an Uno is. But, for those of you who aren't twelve and know what an Uno is, this game is probably for you. Want to play Uno with cards that have Nicolas Cage's face on them? You got it. Eels and Escalators? Sure! A digital version of Space Hulk that isn't completely disappointing? Well, I'm not really a pen-and-paper kinda guy but who knows? Games and gaming objects for any occasion and necessity are available to you, the tabletop-but-not-on-an-actual-tabletop gaming public. "But, Mr. Speedchunk. I don't see the game I want/I have this idea for a game, what do?"Firstly, you don't start a sentence with "but". Secondly, if you don't see something you like, you can make it yourself.  The customization is flexible enough to be part of Cirque Du Soleil probably.You can even flip the table if you feel the rage overcome you. So if you have friends and want to simulate some tables, go ahead and play this game.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 17, 2014
Early Access Review
								Since I was a child I have been fascinated with board and card games. I can think of no better game than Tabletop Simulator that mirrors this experience. With all the Steam Workshop items as well as the included content this game will give you hours of fun and excitement. If you are into board games this is a game for you!There are some issues with this game that still need to be worked out. Currently, the multiplayer portion of the game is still somewhat broken. You can check out my frustrations with this multiplayer here ( http://steamcommunity.com/app/286160/discussions/0/626329186887989015/ )Like any game on Steam that features multiplayer you WILL ecounter a troll/griefer. The one server I was able to get connected to turned on his mic to some of the most hideous screams, music, sounds, etc until we were able to kick and ban him. Thankfully, there is an option to remove/ban players. Also, if you haven't disabled table flipping there is the potential for someone to come into the game just to take everything out in one single table flipping move.With all that said I still recomend this game. I have had so much fun playing that I turned three of my friends on to this game already. I look forward to seeing the multiplayer connectivity issues corrected in future updates and as always playing more community created content from the Steam Workshop.TL;DR+ Awesome Game-  Multiplayer has issues

Posted: October 8, 2016
												Out of all of the selections available on Steam, Tabletop Simulator is my favorite. If Tabletop simulator went away, I would be severely distraught. Having the option to play the physical games I own in an electronic format is important to me. Sometimes I don't have the time or space to setup a physical game. Sometimes I am on the road for work reasons and isn't practical to cart boardgames with me. I can work on my own games or try variants of existing games without a large monetary investment. Tabletop Simulator is my go to game playing program!

content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												"I Thought This Game Was Cool Before It Won An Award"But besides that, I haven't come across any other software that mimics a 'virtual table' as good as this one has (especially with the [currently in development] VR support).* Simple to use* Easy to make custom content (at least, with some computer knowledge)* Built-in Online multiplayer* Vast array of existing games on the Workshop* Large friendly communityThis has become my software of choice when prototyping my own custom games with (I have spent many weekends making custom cards, boards, tiles, dice, etc for importing) and made it possible to easily play these games with friends and family from across the world.If you or your friends are into playing (or making!) board games (or similar), then I can't recommend this enough!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2016
												Tabletop Simulator aims to be the ideal platform to play games, traditionally limited to physical contact, anywhere in the world with anyone you want. This game has bridged long distance friendships and keeps board game night going no matter the distance. The game just gives you a sandbox to play in and doesn't force any tabletop game's rules on the players, this allows for any complexity of game to be played. All you need is to scan the board game's assets into the computer to play it digitally with friends. Have no idea how to do that? That's OK because one of this game's biggest strengths is it's mod support. Check out the Workshop and you will most likely find what you are looking for. I think this game should be a must have for anyone who enjoys traditional board, card and tabletop games.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
												Tabletop Simulator is not a game.  Tabletop Simulator is a system for playing board and card games.  It does this fairly well, and if you have a group of nerdy friends that are all willing to learn to use an initially awkward interface you can have fun with it.  If you don't, there are public rooms available for games.    This game is quite useful if you design your own board games and are looking for a way to test your prototypes with people online.  There are a few communities of people that trade playtesting on this service.

content:
Posted: July 9, 2016
 If you enjoy board games and have friends to play with, I strongly recommend Tabletop Simulator for everyone. ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~+++  Timeless game with infinite board gaming potential +++ Makes you able to play board games with friends living anywhere in the world+++ Great number of workshop mods available++ You are able to create your own game or port an existing one++ Satisfying interaction with pieces and board++ Supports automation via scripting++ Only the host needs to buy the DLC content for all players to be able to play it+ Good physics+ VR Support- Official DLC prices seems a tad bit expensive comparing with the content you can get for free- You need a fixed group of friends who also own this game to play most of the content-- Very heavy load on your computer's RAM, definitely needs more optimization---  A wide variety of bugs, connection failures and crashes (at the time of this review) that can be very frustrating ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

content:
Posted: April 20, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game fits any persons desire to play board games and card games.  It comes highly reccomended, but you must realize thtat right now it is still in Early Access and the game has many flaws.  Some of which right now include occasional hard lag spikes, limited boards, and RPG options. However, it has come very apparent that Berserk games is very hell bent on making this work, so I would not be scared of this turning into a no full release early access game like many in this genre.Tabletop Simulator is wonderful in so many ways.  If your like me, Board Games are super fun but harder to get people to come around a table just to play them.  Tabletop Simulator is full of people from all sorts of places ready to play a simple universal game like checkers and chess.  What I love the most is the RPG options, although limited, are still in the game.  I always wanted to DnD, so this makes it easier to get into it without having to buy a bunch of peices. They do plan on expanding these options as well as many more.Finally, the biggest apeal to Tabletop Simulator is the costumization features.  People are playing ONLINE games of Uno, Monoply, and the very popular Cards Against Humanity in mere seconds.  I have also found people making their own boards or making their own games with the features in the game and playing their own wacky crap online.Overall, Tabletop Simulator comes highly reccomended to anyone.  The creativity is flowing more and more everyday from the users, and the game has only just begun.

content:
Posted: August 2, 2015
												A very robust engine for letting you play tabletop games with your friends online.A review for this game is not especially helpful as I can only really review the engine itself, and whether or not you have fun comes down to if you can use the program in the right way.  A game played in Tabletop Simulator is only as good as the mod creator made it to be.  A TRPG is only going to be as fun as the people you play with.  That's just how it works.Your first step should be to look at the Steam Workshop for a few games you might be looking to play with your friends, or think about which you might want to work on yourself.  I myself added a mod to the workshop for a now-defunct CCG, and it wasn't too hard.  Adding some resources for modding could be an important improvement from the devs, but with a little elbow grease, reddit / steam forum searching, and google you can find the answers you need without difficulty.If you've got some tabletop games you want to play online, this is the tool for you.  Still receives regular updates too.

content:
Posted: April 20, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game fits any persons desire to play board games and card games.  It comes highly reccomended, but you must realize thtat right now it is still in Early Access and the game has many flaws.  Some of which right now include occasional hard lag spikes, limited boards, and RPG options. However, it has come very apparent that Berserk games is very hell bent on making this work, so I would not be scared of this turning into a no full release early access game like many in this genre.Tabletop Simulator is wonderful in so many ways.  If your like me, Board Games are super fun but harder to get people to come around a table just to play them.  Tabletop Simulator is full of people from all sorts of places ready to play a simple universal game like checkers and chess.  What I love the most is the RPG options, although limited, are still in the game.  I always wanted to DnD, so this makes it easier to get into it without having to buy a bunch of peices. They do plan on expanding these options as well as many more.Finally, the biggest apeal to Tabletop Simulator is the costumization features.  People are playing ONLINE games of Uno, Monoply, and the very popular Cards Against Humanity in mere seconds.  I have also found people making their own boards or making their own games with the features in the game and playing their own wacky crap online.Overall, Tabletop Simulator comes highly reccomended to anyone.  The creativity is flowing more and more everyday from the users, and the game has only just begun.

content:
Posted: July 9, 2015
												Imagine a world where games ranging from Chess, Clue, Yugioh, Magic The Gathering, even Eels and Escalators, are all free and playable after purchasing Tabletop Simulator. Welcome to that world. In all seriousness, this game is amazing. The community workshop offers a wide variety of downloadable mods, which let you play all the classic games you remember growing up playing, or games you wish you played. And once you download the mod with your favorite game, you can play with other people online! And have a blast while doing so! I highly recommend this game, It's a blast with friends. Give it a shot!10/10.

content:
Posted: October 20, 2016
												Newish player (purple) joins game of Secret Hitler.  Is assigned role of Hitler after being very trustworthy in first two games.  Facists know Hitler, Hitler does not know Facists.  First policy is Liberal.  Purple player approves and listens for conflicts.  Yellow chooses Purple as Chancellor.  Unanimous "jai".  Yellow hands over a Liberal and Facist card.  Purple Hitler dumps Liberal, adds Facist, says no choice.  Yellow backs up the triple Facist claim.  Purple instantly identifies a Facist.Eventually, Green and Blue are caught in a conflict, with people pointing at Blue (later inspected by Green, claimed Liberal).  Poor Blue later gets shot.  Purple Hitler was one of the voices leading to this shot.Purple Hitler is selected again for Chancellor with a chance to win.  Downvoted due to Liberal strategy trying to get a certain President.  Later, Purple becomes President with 5 Facist out.  Selects someone he thinks is Liberal.  Vote gets approved.  Draws 3 Facist cards.  Shows them on table confirming sixth will come to win regaardless, then shows Hitler card to shock and amazement.Purple was me.10/10 would lie again.

content:
Posted: April 23
												While I do have a serious problem with the fact that you are not supporting the company by playing it through tabletop simulator I will say it is a great game.Pro- One of the Easiest ways to play games with friends period. If many of your friends live quite a distance from you this is a very easy way to stay in touch and have fun at the same time!- Many people in the community make their own games, many tools are supported to be able to do this and almost nothing limits the creatiability.- The community is usually very friendly. Yes theres always that one guy who likes to come around all the time but it is mostly fine. People are almost always ok with teaching you new games and are ok with being patient as you learn the controls.Cons- The controls can be difficult to learn as a newer player, ive played for almost 1,400 hours at this point and i still do not know some of them to be honest.- Again as i said before i think there should be a better way to support the actual creators. There is some DLC that you can purchase for some games namely Cosmic Encounter which as far as i know does go back a little to the company.Overall i would reccomend this product though it can be a little annoying to newer players to get used to.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 4
												My review will concentrate on 3 areas:1) The simulator itself, and provided (free) and pay content - In a word, delightful. An easy interface, and the ability to connect and play with friends the world over is really cool. Great visuals, and of course the sandbox nature encourages a lot of DIY. For $20, it's hard to beat the value of this app, especially if you are a fan of games that require thought, strategy, and a human opponent to make them their most satisfying and entertaining.2) Out-of-print, rare, old games - The potential for bringing back many out-of-print, never-to-be reprinted games (old SPI, Avalon Hill, etc.) is pretty great, especially with the prices some people are asking for copies on eBay. I understand that someone, somewhere has the "rights" to these titles, but as long as they are not using them. I fully intend to try to digitize at least one of my favorites, or at least assist others in creating more content, particularly in the area of wargames.  VASSAL is also great for many of these, but take a hybrid card/counter/hex map/character sheet/encounter book game like the great WW2 infantry solitaire title, Ambush! - the VASSAL interface just isn't made for it. But I think TTS might just fit the bill.3) Existing, in print, readily available modern games. As many reviewers have stated, it's an uneasy feeling. As a musician, I've seen the changes in the recording industry over the past two decades, and how difficult i(nearly impossible) it is to make a living as a recording artist these days. For the consumer, it's the problem of too many great games, too little time and money. My hope is that publishers are looking at what's going on here and hoping that the chance to experience their products on TTS will drive physical sales, and I will admit - I've bought a ton of X-Wing stuff, although that was largely driven by the fact of playing on VASSAL (where you need the pilot cards, secondary weapon/mod cards, damage decks, etc.) in order to play. But as I learn to play on VASSAL and on TTS, it does increase my desire to play face-to-face with friends and family, and that has also contributed to my acquiring physical expansions. I also know that at the moment, I am concentrating much of my TTS time on X-Wing, even though I have subscribed to MANY other games.In closing, you should come play. It's a lot of fun!

content:
Posted: May 15, 2014
												Update Time:Between this and Gmod, this takes the cake for the "Game within a Game" award.With its active community of players and the ability to find new and interesting tabletop games, there is no end to the amount of evenings one can spend laughing and having fun. And with the scripting engine getting better each update, fully scripted gamemodes are starting to pop up more and more.--Original ReviewThis is something I have been waiting for. While there are many types of tabletop simulators for games avaialble, none of them ever trully felt like you were at a table, and all of them were specifically made for one type or style of game.This simulator feels like a table.Secondly, the custom deck tool, while a bit annoying to work with due to having to hand crop and form the image, is amazing.I have been using it to try out magic decks. A fair warning however, it does not like it when you have more then a million cards in one deck. I learned this due to testing a squirrel token deck. Eventually I would like to see the custom deck tool be able to use images on your computer and then send those to the other players instead of having to rely on other sites to host the deck image, but  that is my only major gripe about it. If you need a deck larger then 69 cards, just make multilpe deck images and import them to form the deck.I did not mess with much of the other games except the rpg pack, which I found to be incedibly fun to use, if a little limited in content for now. Once the workshop hits, that should be quickly eleviated.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
Early Access Review
								Note: Early Access ReviewTabletop simulator is more then just a table flipping simulator (which the devs seem really proud of), it is a game where you can play most any tabletop game. I mostly play board games and card games. I bought this game because I don't have many friends who like to play tabletop games with me. I think if you really want to play more board games and card games but nobody will play them with you irl, you might want to give TTS a try. I say might because you're going to have to deal with a few things. I'd say this game is ideal to play with your friends, if you have friends willing to pitch in for the four pack, definately go for it, you're going to have alot of fun. If you just bought it and plan on playing public games like me, you will have to deal with the occasional troll, people leaving early sometimes, etc. Here is a condensed pro con list about the game.Pros-Practically unlimited content with stream workshop support for the games you know and love  <- great if you like learning new games too.-Realistic enough 3d physics-Practically no lag-Autosave feature combined with kick and ban function makes dealing with trolls painless. -Developers frequently update the game, normally once every one or two weeks. -Good community for the most part. Cons-Most of the rooms are locked, normally 2-3 public games open at a time-Playing public games aren't as fun as with your friends-No single player (besides solitaire and other single player games)Overall I personally really like this game, and I look forward to more features and more games being added to the workshop. Since buying this I've probably learned about 10 new games and enjoy playing classics as well.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 24, 2014
Early Access Review
								I'll be honest. When Tabletop Simulator first came out, I dismissed it as a Goat Simulator successor. Just for the joke of hey, there's board games, you played for 1 hour, and now we have your 15 dollars. But, eventually me and my brother decided to give it a try.Please don't classify this with Goat Simulator. Upon booting it up, I immediately discovered that this is a legit simulator. It has everything a simulator needs, really. Beautiful graphics, nice boards, just overall solid feel. One thing that I was amazed with was the physics in this game. You can flip the board table, and watch all of the pieces on the board fly until they disappear into nothingness. Everything acts like it should in real life. Singleplayer mode feels like a really zen experience. But, multiplayer mode is where the fun really happens. With up to 8 players, it can get pretty hectic pretty fast. While the main board with the game are excellent, some of the community made games deserve a mention too, like Uno and even Candyland. It really is a social game. Because it is an Early Access title, new games and boards will no doubt be added in the future. I would reccommend convincing your friends to get it as well, because this game only gets better with each friend playing.Ranking: 9/10Buy it? Definitely

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
												Tabletop Simulator is one of the most interesting and exciting PC games I've seen in a long time. Its got me rethinking what a digital game is and has potentially limitless depth. I must say that the developers have done a pretty lousy job marketing their own product- there’s a lot more to this than the table flip.In case you don't know, and the name isn't obvious enough, Tabletop Simulator it is a simulator of physical games. Tabletop Sim isn’t really a computer game in the normal sense as the software doesn’t regulate moves, rules and victory conditions. I wouldn’t go as far to say that Steam should classify this as ‘software’, but it is indeed less a game and more a tool for playing games.To play the games you manipulate physics-based objects in the exact same way you’d use a physical table. If you have to move a piece 3 spaces then you must grab the piece with your virtual hand and move it one, two, three spaces. Dice rolls aren’t a random number generator you click on- they’re modelled three-dimensional objects you have to toss across the table- just don’t be over-zealous and pelt them off the table. Actions like that make Tabletop Sim far more immersive than any other digital board game conversions.The controls are very smartly designed and cover pretty much all of the actions you would want to take when handling dice, models or cards. You can easily flip and rotate anything. If you throw any cards in your direction, they will snap into a hand area, obscuring their faces from the other players. Its smart decisions like this that prevent the virtual hand from becoming too cumbersome to manipulate with a mouse. The devs have succeeded in simplifying the most repetitive actions you’d perform with a board/card game. Some tasks are easier to do in TS than real life like the ability to shuffle cards by just shaking the mouse or the ability to snap placed objects onto a grid. I also must praise the ability to see a close-up of a card at anytime by holding alt. That one feature has probably saved me a ridiculous amount of time moving the camera. There is also controller support that I’m yet to try out myself.Tabletop Sim really does just give the players some objects on flat surface. Its up to the humans involved to follow the rules and maintain a semblance of order. In spite of the inclusion of some admin powers, the potential for griefing is great. That is, if you were to play with strangers. In the 30+ hours I’ve played Tabletop Simulator, its always been with a small group of internet buddies with a skype chat running in the background. Its perfectly possible to play games with strangers- there is a standard server browser- but on a personal, social basis, I can’t bring myself to jump into a random server as TS requires chat. Perhaps there are more outgoing people out there than me but if I play a board game then I personally would choose to sit at a table with friends rather than with strangers. This review is now veering in a more personal direction so it would suffice to say that I can’t completely exclude the possibility of using TS as a way of meeting new people. Board games are relatively slow affairs compared to video games and are therefore excellent pastimes for socialising. You can even goof off while waiting for your slow friend, flinging coins in their direction and inflating the size of cards… which is slightly less a ‘simulation’ but its all good, stupid fun.Honestly, in reviewing Tabletop Simulator I have to get into the very appeal of board and card games as a whole. The impressive quality of TS is that it can take all of into the digital realm. The two main benefits of this transition are:You can play board games with your friends across the internet, including the friends you’ll most likely never meet in person.TS could theoretically offer unlimited games developed by other players all of which are untethered by any restrictions hard-coded into the software.That second point is a bit of a legal and perhaps even moral issue- so lets elaborate on it. Tabletop Simulator has mod support. This means that anyone can replicate any board game to have ever existed. There are perhaps some that can’t be 100% accurately remade but with custom models there are very few limits. For deckbuilding games such as Magic The Gathering you can independently make a deck in one mod, save it, then carry that across into another game to pit it against an opponent (who is wielding their own custom deck).Mods that use copyrighted assets are nothing new but these mods let you replicate the game experience as a whole. Imagine LittleBigPlanet let you download the original Super Mario Brothers. Not as a reskin of the floatly Sackboy adventures but as a replication so accurate you might as well be playing the game on a NES emulator. It would be a legal nightmare and the mods of TS very much border on this concept.I haven’t heard of anything too controversial on the Tabletop Sim front, but that may be because of how relatively obscure it is at the moment. Whether or not these mods do indeed break any laws isn’t my decision to make. As it stands, the issue is whether or not you, the player, have a problem with it . To be perfectly honest, I don’t have a problem with it at all and actually consider the mods to be the main selling point of the product. Perhaps I was wrong about the poor marketing; perhaps the devs chose to hold that particular selling point closer to their chest.For me, having mods is like having access to an unlimited toy-box and the vast majority of my time has been dedicated to playing copyrighted material (particularly Dominion). To defend the mods (and possibly justify my own use of them) these game are still mere recreations of the real products. One could argue that playing mods may encourage more people to buy the real physical board game. I know my numerous online sessions of Dominion has encouraged me to play more of it in person, which I have done so. I also look forward to buying my next expansion pack soon.Tabletop Sim also includes some standard copyright-free games such as chess and reversi. There are normal decks of playing cards and given how many games you can play with those alone TS may still be a sound investment without requiring mods. The truly creative may use the mod capabilities to create their own original games. TS may even prove to be an ample testing ground for new board game designs.Tabletop Simulator is an excellent union of digital games and traditional physical games. It’s a testament to the fact that board games have social qualities that a digital game will never be able to replicate- even if that amounts to nothing more than being able to fling the pieces around like an idiot. It should go without saying at this point but this should not be purchased if you have zero interest in playing with others. Solitaire only goes so far. This is a social game. Buy it with the intention to play with friends. If all of this sounds appealing to you, it may even be worth buying Tabletop Simulator in a pack of 4, as I did. This ensures that you’ll have some people to play with and may even prove to be one of the best gaming purchases you’ve ever made. It did for me.EDIT: The game has since left early access and continues to improve with smart game additions.

Posted: November 25, 2016
												Tabletop Simulator is the kind of game you are either going to play once for an hour with some friends, or spend hundreds of hours with your friends playing a variety of board games. The community support behind this game is excellent, and there's is a massive host of games that you can get. Quite the excellent purchase, not only economically ($20 CAD or $10 on sale) but it also provides a unique experience for those of us who can't get together in person to play board games. The automatic scripting that some of the mod creators have put into their games can often times save loads of preparation time,  while enhancing the games themsleves by automatics many tiresome features. This game is definately worth the purchase if you have friends to play with on a somewhat regular basis.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												Tabeltop Simulator by itself is a barebones user interface that gives you a digital space to play tabletop games: A table, a background, game pieces, and simple UI tools to manipulate game pieces.Where Tabletop Simulator shines is the Steam Workshop Community.  In fact, I would say the longevity of this software/game entirely is dependant on the efforts of the community.  The active community is always creating new game assets and digitizing popular board games.This game is really the best way to connect with friends who cannot get together physically to play board games or role playing games.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2016
												I feel like this game should be standard in everyone's library. It's literally exactly what the name of the game implies. Being able to simulate what people do on a tabletop is exactly what this game is. There are no limits to what you can do when it comes to boardgames, cardgames, etc.Recommendation: If you pick this game up (which you should totally do) be sure to get your friends to get it and give "Secret Hitler" a go. it's tons of fun and you'll discover mroe and more games to play on here.Have a blast!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2016
												This is a great implimentation of a physics simulator to do literally any board game that might be there.  I enjoy it as this allows me to play on days that I would rather stay home in my pajamas but still get some gaming and social time with my friends, not to mention some friends who live in other states.  Not all games work as you would expect but there are a whole lot more hits than misses in this.  The steam workshop for this game seems lively and there seems to be a lot of content being made on a regular basis.  This is also easy on older PCs as some of my friends have PCs that can't handle most digital board games out there due to particles and such.  All and all, a big recommendation from me.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 4
												Worth every penny. The amount of board games available from the community is amazing to the point where it is almost impossible to measure the amount of value this game has. One board game from a local book store would run you, on average, $40. For one $20 purchase on Steam (I paid $10 when this was on sale) you can have access to thousands of board games. If you're wondering if you should buy this game ask yourself one simple question: do you like board games? If the answer is yes, buy this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 9
												When I first got this game, I didn't think much of it."Oh, cool. I like tabletop games," I thought to myself.Dear God was I wrong. I was so wrong. This game is scripture to me. The community are full of genuinely nice and funny people, only some of who happen to share idealogy with an infamous German dictator. The games they play consist of Secret Hitler, Uno, Cards Against Humanity (which I think isn't as good in the simulation), and other stuff nobody has really heard of or cares about.When I'm not collecting lotion or vintage cat figurines, I am ALWAYS playing this game. It's the greatest game ever made.

content:
Posted: February 23
												C'mon, you can flip the table when you win!  Or lose!The beauty of this game is that, in a nutshell, you're given all the bits and then you play with little to no guidance beyond basic controls.  You either play the game right, play the game wrong, or you throw around a bowl full of dominoes and play bowling with oversized chess pieces while "Through The Fire and Flames" is blaring on a virtual iPad.  I don't think there's any better way of playing board games online.

								This game isn't just about flipping tables.  Thats all fun, but this game is amazing. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								Even with current glitches and wonky keyboard mouse controls as of this review, this game has blown me away. And that is saying something considering I barely play board games, but used this as a tool to learn a new one with friends across the country.Current VR support is mostly unusable, because the screens on the Vive are so resolution, it's near impossible to play any games you don't know by heart and it's very annoying to zoom in and out to read text. There should be ways to pin cameras around the board so you can reference rule books or played card areas quickly.For years, physical card games and video games have been seperated. Video game clones for card games almost always suck or are incredibly limited. Not so anymore. This lets you take having to store a ton of boxes and being present with multiple other people and makes everything super accessible!I love seeing brand new board games like Scythe embrace the concept of Table Simulator by offering their game for $8 here or something like $50 for the paper board game version.

content:
Posted: January 25, 2015
												Tabletop Sim makes it possible to play virtually any board game over the internet...properaly. It comes preset with some classics (Chess, Checkers etc), along with lots of objects you may use for other board games (dice, various tokens, even monsters that actually move if you want to setup a role-playing game), as well as the tools to creating your own board game. Having Steam Workshop makes this game have endless replayibility, where you can download and play virtually any card/board game you can think of (Munchkins is really popular on here). Although most of these mods are copyrighted, and they have a chance to be removed. Tabletop Sim has straightforward UI, with a very quick tutorial to get you used to basic controls. Hosting a game is extremely easy, and it's very stable as long as you don't load up too many objects. Go for it. ...and I thank the devs for supporting Linux :D

								A really cool game, that is like realistic game board, where you can do anything with any game boards possible. Really great for a Surface Pro 3, as it meets the full requirements of specs. This is really when you're bored, you have nothing else to do, and you got time to waste on, this is the game for you. For others to play, they need a steam account I think, and just buy the game. I love flipping the table over, of course. This is the ultimate sandbox game I've ever seen on Steam, beside Valve's "Garry's Mod." I wish there were more of these games that are on Steam...

content:
Posted: February 14, 2015
Early Access Review
								Multiplayer could be better.There needs to be a better way to find games to play and people to play with than just jumping into a random server and hoping you find a game to play.  And I know what you're thinking - "Just make your own server then, with the game you want to play." Yeah sure, I could. But then I'd just be sitting there alone, possibly for hours, waiting and hoping someone jumps in to play with me. There should be a central lobby for people to meet and say, "I'd like to play Game X, does anyone else?" Instead of hoping to find something in the server list, and possibly not finding anything. I still reccommed this game however.  Because when you DO find a game to play, it's a fun experience, and Voice chat helps a lot.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 7, 2015
Early Access Review
								We all know how it is in real life...Yeah, you know.You find out about and game like Yugioh or Magic and you realize "I'm going to have to spend money to make my own decks!" Cool idea...but not if you are on a budget. Or lets say you come across a game you've never even heard of! You try to go to the store and find out they have no idea what you are talking about (maybe the game is only in a specific region). Or maybe you wanna play some poker/checkers/dice games and you just got no friends....(insert crowd going "Awwww")WELL THEN MY FRIEND, THIS IS YOUR GAME! The game allows you to play ANY kind of board game, card game, dice game, etc.! And guess what? You only have to pay 1 fee...yeah you heard me, 1. Just buy this game, go into the workshop, subscribe to a game you want in your TS Library and play games with your friends or heck go take it multiplayer and play with complete strangers (who knows maybe even make more friends!).The game gives you the ability to even have a tablet and that allows you to stream music/videos to anyone in the game room with you (so long as you are in control of said tablet). The last cool thing I wanna mention to you all is that once you are all done with a game, you can flip the table and have a slight chuckle as everything goes everywhere!This game is a game that ANY steam, no, ANYONE who has a computer should own. Buy it now guys, you won't be sorry.

content:
Posted: March 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								I was interested when I first heard of this game back when it was on Kickstarter. I regret not getting the game earlier then and helping the developers out with my money.Since getting this game I've had fun playing tabletop games with friends whom I don't get to see in person as often.On top of a bunch of classical games (Chess, checkers, etc) the modding community for this game is HUGE, allowing many games to be created or imported (Cards Against Humanity, Monopoly, MTG, etc, etc, etc, etc).While this game is still (as of the time of writing this) in an early access phase there aren't many bugs or errors you'd expect in some other early access games. The worst bug you can expect is random crashes, but those are few and far between (in some cases it is the mod's fault and not the game's, such as having very large file sizes that wrecks your computer).All that being said, I highly recommend this game and would like to commend the developers for delivering a great product. I cannot wait to see what else can be added / refined as this game grows.

content:
Posted: March 31, 2015
Early Access Review
								Like board games? Card Games? Minatures games? pen and paper RPGs? Then you'll like this! It does exactly what it says on the tin. Hundreds of mods on the workshop to replicate anything from long-dead CCGs to modern board games. There are a few rough edges owing to it being in early access, but so far this seems to be one of the good ones. It plays perfectly well, just has a few finnicky little things here and there (exiting the program by closing the window always results in an error message, for example). But it's perfectly stable while you're playing.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 4, 2015
												This simulator shows more potential in gaming than anything I've seen since I first discovered emulators. The workshop community has already created a lifetime's worth of amazing board games, collectable card games, and others that are very playable.Tabletop Simulator makes for an incredible party trick and it's in no small part due to the amazing workshop community that is supporting this game. Already nearly every board game or card game I could think of has been recreated in some fashion. It seems they are being updated frequently as well.I've read that there are not plans to add in AI, yet I've already played Connect 4 against a bot online that was enforcing the simple rules of that game. This is very encouraging. It'd still be very easy to troll if one so desired, but by having the option to create and control your own games helps quite a bit and there's a step back feature which is nice. Personally, I don't see many of my friends jumping on this with me and actually playing games with me though. I sure would have loved to have had this as a teenager.As with any digital simulation, this will never be as good as the real thing, but the benefit of having such a large catalog of games to choose from is an easy draw as well. I'm already daydreaming about building some kind of table touch screen computer specifically for this game. I could see this being a fun way to do game nights, though the novelty would probably wear off after while and ultimitately you'd wish you were playing on real board games with real pieces. However, the benefit of having such an amazing catalog of games available virtually also has its clear benefits.I could see myself getting back into Magic the Gathering and other collectible card games because of this program since I don't have to shell out tons of money to get the desired cards for a certain deck. On this topic, this simulator could really use a search feature of some kind to sort through all the objects available to players. At the moment, building a Magic deck seems like quite a chore, one I'm willing to take on, but probably not one any of my friends would tackle. Maybe I just need more Magic playing friends. If I could conjure up cards by routing through a database and select cards that way, that'd be freaking insane.Local multiplayer works well except a lot of games involve cards and therefore hinge on the idea of everyone being honest and not looking at the screen during a player's turn. If player's could check their hands and play cards via their smart phones, just.... oh man. That'd be the game changer for me.As it sits, Tabletop Simulator is neat as hell. You'll enjoy messing around with it, probably play some games online and hopefully get a couple friends to play you in chess or something. If you don't already know how to play a game, playing on Tabletop Simulator is probably not the best way to learn, but it's doable. Definitely recommend checking this out. It could be the start of something much better.
